title: Joy is the rocket fuel that can transform society and politics
content:

Joy is one of the most underrated qualities in politics but among the most powerful assets a candidate can possess .
Jeb Bush , the son and brother of US presidents , recognises the centrality of joy to a successful political life . He is often touted as a key contender for the 2016 presidential race , during which there is a high chance he would face Hillary Clinton as the Democratic challenger .
Mr Bush , a former Florida governor , recently responded to the speculation by saying he would base his decision on whether he could do it “ joyfully ” .
He said he was going to “ think about it really hard , ” adding : “ The thinking part is not really related to the politics of all this , but whether I can do it with joy in my heart and whether it ’ s going to be right for my family . ”
Joy is much more than feeling upbeat – it is the energising delight in recognising that one has been trusted with a position of incredible privilege and responsibility and purpose . If a politician is blessed to do this job in the company of talented and committed people there will be camaraderie , courage and , when needed , comfort .
The spectacle of politicians who no longer feelsjoy in their role is deeply sad . When running against President Obama in 2012 , Mitt Romney was forced to effectively disown his past as a moderate governor of Massachusetts who secured universal healthcare coverage and built bridges with communities who traditionally would have seen Republicans as foes .
As he speedboated rightwards during successive debates during the primary season his zeal for the job seemed to evaporate and he failed to persuade a majority of Americans to put him in the White House . Tony Blair ’ s leadership seemed weakest when he could no longer hide internal angst and the departure of key staff gave the impression of a deepening loneliness ; Gordon Brown rarely appeared to find joy in the job he had coveted so deeply .
In contrast , Bill Clinton survived torrid scandals in part because his joy at meeting the public and his passion for ideas was never anything less than incandescent . For him , a handshake was not a security risk but a connection to a personal electricity supply ; this empathy inspired a trust that his detractors could not match .
It was partly an internal dynamo of glee that enabled Rhodri Morgan to lead Labour in Wales for just short of a decade and leave with stratospheric approval rating . There were plenty of times when he was in trouble , when the party under-performed or his decisions were ridiculed and he found himself under sustained fire , but he never exhibited self-pity , his sense of humour rarely faltered , and he never gave the suggestion he would rather be elsewhere .
Mark Twain said that to get “ the full value of joy you must have someone to divide it with ” and Mr Morgan , doubtless , drew strength and energy from his relationship with his wife and fellow politician , Julie . He also had a fiercely loyal set of advisers and continued to take pleasure in sport , swimming at Mwnt , entertaining grandchildren and reading widely .
Such diversions are not distractions from politics but provide a vital sense of perspective to any leader who would otherwise reel under the pulverising weight of responsibilities .
William Wilberforce , the pioneering anti-slavery campaigner , was famed for breaking social conventions and playing with his children . He would play marbles and run races with his offspring and , according to biographer John Pollock , found comfort in the din they created , telling a friend : “ What a blessing to have these dear children ! Only think what a relief , amidst other hurries , to hear their voices and know they are well . ”
Joy in politics injects hope rather than glibness into serious work and can renew the strength for daily battles .
The Irish playright Seán O ’ Casey argued : “ Laughter is wine for the soul - laughter soft , or loud and deep , tinged through with seriousness - the hilarious declaration made by man that life is worth living . ”
Leading African-American theologian Cornel West speaks of subversive joy , stating : “ Nonmarket values of love and care and service and laughter and joy run counter to that seriousness of maximising personal preferences and maximising profits ... So you get this fascinating juxtaposition of the joy and the pain and the despair and the hope all linked together . ”
Similarly the writer Howard Wolfson recently argued that the much-missed musician Pete Seeger taught Bruce Springsteen that songs could push for social change and yet ring with joy , writing : “ Seeger showed Springsteen that political music could be buoyant , even as it dealt with the weightiest issues ... When Springsteen asked , ‘ How can a poor man stand such times as this ? ’ the answer was clear – by singing joyously together , and finding common purpose through shared voice . ”
Dietrich Bonhoeffer , the priest executed for his role in a plot against Hitler , saw a vital role for music , saying how it will “ help dissolve your perplexities and purify your character and sensibilities , and in time of care and sorrow , will keep a fountain of joy alive in you . ”
Such a fountain could refresh Westminster . A great political leader will unite his or her party in shared voice and common purpose – and a ready supply of bear-hugs and a wisely chosen iPod-playlist could make the winning difference .
